item.title: Claiming the Arts for Christ ft. Ryan Lauterio [Open Mike with Michael Thiessen]
item.description:
OPEN MIKE w/Michael Thiessen ~ August 17, 2024
On this episode of Open Mike, Dr. Thiessen is joined by Ryan Lauterio, founder of the Maker Institute (https://themakerinstitute.org/). The conversation explores the limits and boundaries of art about faith and worship. It discusses the importance of explicit appeal and the need for artists to claim the name of Jesus. The church's role in supporting and encouraging the arts is also examined, focusing on the need for a robust artistic theology. The conversation raises questions about using art in worship and the potential pitfalls of using art to sell the church to the culture. The talk explores the role of art in worship and the church. They discuss the use of drama and visual arts in church services, the regulatory principle, and the potential pitfalls of misusing art. They emphasize the importance of understanding the purpose and motive behind using art in worship and the need to avoid gimmicks and self-idolatry. They also discuss the significance of silence in worship and the role of art in other aspects of life, such as vocation and culture. The conversation concludes with a call to commission artists and encourage them to use their talents for the glory of God.

item.title: Glorifying God Through Great Art ft. Ryan Lauterio [Open Mike with Michael Thiessen]
item.description:
OPEN MIKE w/Michael Thiessen ~ August 03, 2024
On this episode of Open Mike, Dr. Thiessen is joined by Ryan Lauterio, founder of the Maker Institute, who discusses the importance of art in the Christian faith and the need for Christians to engage in the arts. He emphasizes that art is not neutral and can it be. It's either humanizing or dehumanizing in accord with the Word of God. Lauterio encourages Christians to be grateful for the arts and to push for excellence in their creative endeavors. He also addresses the false dilemma of quality versus budget, stating that Christians can make good art without needing a large budget. Lauterio calls for the church to take a vested interest in supporting and promoting Christian art.
